contentrichtext.text: '''JMC''', or '''Jim Melton Cyclery''' was a [[bicycle]] [[company (law)|company]] in the 1970s and 1980s. It started as a bicycle shop in 1969. It began manufacturing bicycle components in 1974, mostly to make a bicycle look more like a motocross motorcycle, including fenders and false fuel tanks. In 1977 JMC began manufacturing [[bicycle motocross]] (BMX) bicycles.<ref>[http://www.jmcbmx.com/about.htm History]{{dead link|date=November 2010}}</ref> During the 1970s it sponsored racers in BMX. Riders sponsored by JMC include [[Harry Leary]], [[Clint Miller]], [[Tinker Juarez]], and [[Darrell Young]]. By 1979 the bicycle shop was sold and the company owned just the factory. Sales peaked in 1981 when it was number two of the [[American Bicycle Association]] title for top BMX factory team three years in a row.<ref>''BMX Plus!'' September 1985 Vol.8 No.9 pg.12</ref> Jim Melton folded the company in July 1985 because, in addition of his wife Vera's poor heath,<ref>''BMX Plus!'' September 1985 Vol.8 No.9 pg.12</ref> he was proud of his bikes being made in America and did not want to move production to Taiwan as others were doing. ==Models== The JMC Black Shadow was the most desirable of their models with a reputation for light weight and an excellent black finish. ==End Note== <references/> ==External links== {{DEFAULTSORT:Jmc Bicycles}} [[Category:Cycle manufacturers of the United States]] {{cycle-manufacturer-stub}}
